awd_titl_txt: Degradation of Chlorinated Contaminants at Mineral - Water Interface: The Engineered vs. Natural Surfaces of Sulfide Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Environmental Chemical Sciences Program in the Chemistry Division at the National Science Foundation, Professors Weile Yan and Kayleigh Millerick from Texas Tech University (TTU) investigate a class of surface sulfided iron materials, which may have potential to degrade chlorinated molecules (specifically ethenes) in the sub-surface environment. It is hypothesized that controlled sulfidation of iron metal (Fe(0)) through chemical or biological means creates surfaces that have significantly enhanced reactivity towards chlorinated ethenes.  This study explores the use of environmentally-compatible reactive surfaces for in situ abatement of persistent groundwater contaminants. This research provides a training ground for undergraduate and graduate researchers to engage in multidisciplinary investigations in environmental biogeochemistry and remediation. The findings are incorporated into a new course on Environmental Interfacial Chemistry. In addition, the investigators develop experiment kits and introduce the subject of groundwater contamination to K-12 students through science enrichment programs at TTU.
  
The investigators take an integrated experimental approach to probe the relationship between the chemistry of the sulfided materials prepared under different conditions and the reactions of perchloroethene (PCE) and trichloroethene (TCE) on these reactive surfaces. Key factors controlling the rates and pathways of PCE and TCE degradation on these surfaces are elucidated through kinetic and isotopic investigations. The interface between a sulfided overlayer and an Fe(0) phase provides a sustained driving force against oxidative passivation in the environmental media.  The transformation of surface sulfided iron and natural iron sulfides in groundwater environment, particularly under the influence of pertinent biogeochemical processes, are studied.  This study advances the fundamental understanding of interactions between chlorinated ethenes and reactive surfaces that are either introduced by engineering intervention or naturally present in the subsurface environment.  This study explores in situ abatement of persistent groundwater contaminants and trains undergraduate and graduate researchers to engage in multidisciplinary investigations in environmental biogeochemistry and remediation.

Project Objectives and Scope of Work

This project aimed to investigate the effects of surface sulfur amendment (?sulfidation?) on the reactivity and selectivity of zero-valent iron (ZVI) materials in reductive dechlorination of chloroethenes. Chloroethenes, including tetrachloro-, trichloro-, and dichloroethenes (PCE, TCE and DCEs), are among the most frequently identified chemicals at legacy contamination sites. The project consists of four major tasks. The first two tasks focus on the chemical sulfidation of nanosized and bulk-scale ZVI materials, identifying optimal sulfidation conditions, and investigating mechanisms of sulfur-induced enhancement in contaminant reduction rates. In the third task, the PIs explored the potential of using monoculture or mixed culture of sulfur-reducing bacteria to enable controlled sulfidation of ZVI materials. In the last task, the effects of ZVI on sulfur-reducing bacteria and dechlorinating bacteria were examined, and the long-term stability of sulfur-modified iron in aqueous environment was assessed.

 

Major Outcomes

The findings generated in this study have resulted in four published manuscripts, two manuscripts to be submitted in the near future, and over ten conference posters or oral presentations. The findings constitute major contents in three PhD students? dissertations at Texas Tech University. In addition, a U.S. utility patent, based on the outcome of this research, was granted in 2020. A summary of major technical findings is provided below.

Amending ZVI surface with reduced sulfur species consistently improves the rates of chloroethene reduction. The improvement effects are specific of the contaminant involved and are in the descending order of TCE > trans-DCE > PCE > cis-DCE and 1,1-DCE. Concurrent with the kinetic enhancement are the significant increases in electron utilization efficiency by ZVI. Sulfur modification diverts more electrons (or reductant equivalents) to the contaminants than to background aqueous matrices. Based on mechanistic investigations, the pronounced effects of sulfur on ZVI reactivity are at least partially attributed to the role of sulfur in regulating the formation of reactive hydrogen species on the ZVI surface.

The project also examined the other side of the thesis, that is the response of microbial community and biological activities to the presence of the unadorned and sulfur-modified ZVI.  Microbial investigations show that sulfur-reducing bacteria are generally robust and can generate reduced sulfur species for ZVI surface amendment even when particle concentrations are very high, although at differing kinetic rates.  Rates of sulfur reduction and proliferation of sulfate-reducing bacteria were greatest when bulk-sized ZVI particles of high purity were used.  Nanoscale particles impaired sulfate-reducing activity and enriched active methanogens, but this effect was minimized when nanoscale ZVI was pre-sulfurized.  Findings overall suggest that ZVI surface treatments may reduce the extent to which particles interrupt the metabolic behavior of sulfate-reducing and dechlorinating microbial communities. 

The project confirms that reduced sulfur species generated by sediment-derived microbial sulfate reducing culture, in a dissolved state or in sulfide minerals, can effectively improve the performance of ZVI materials in reductive dechlorination reactions.  This sheds light on the possibility of prolonging or reinstating the surface reactivity of ZVI deployed in the field via biological interventions. It is important in such implementations to ensure that mass transport is not limiting due to excessive mineral formation.

 

Broader Impacts

Degradation of chlorinated solvents using reactive mineral surfaces is a topic of immense interest due to the presence of PCE and TCE at many legacy contamination sites and their persistence in the natural environment. This research explored an innovative approach to remediating sites impacted by chlorinated solvents taking advantage of the synergy between a chemical reducing agent (ZVI) and native or augmented microbial activities. This research trained four graduate and two undergraduate researchers to engage in multidisciplinary investigations in the field of environmental biogeochemistry and subsurface remediation. Three graduate students completed PhD dissertations based on this research, and the research experience have prepared them for their current professional careers in academia and environmental engineering practice. A suite of STEM outreach activities were designed and conducted during the course of the project, providing an early exposure to environmental engineering and science to a diverse group of K-12 students near PI?s institute in the west Texas.
